Key Findings

  • £64 million in total recorded spending across 42,536 transactions (April 2021 to December 2025)
  • 1,525 different suppliers received payments — but spending is concentrated among a small number
  • Very flat spending pattern with no year-end spike — March spending at just 1.1x the monthly average
  • Good data quality: 100% of transactions include descriptions and department information

Overview of Rossendale's Spending

Rossendale Borough Council recorded £64 million in payments over £500 between April 2021 and December 2025, spread across 42,536 individual transactions to 1,525 different suppliers. As a small district council serving approximately 70,000 residents, Rossendale has the smallest budget of the four East Lancashire councils analysed on this platform.

The spending data is notable for its quality. Every transaction includes a description and department attribution — a standard that not all councils meet. Burnley, for example, publishes no transaction descriptions at all, making Rossendale's data considerably more transparent in this respect.

The top five entries account for approximately £12 million — nearly a fifth of total spend. Capita alone represents 9% of all recorded expenditure. This level of concentration is not unusual for a small district council with limited in-house capacity, but it does mean a small number of organisations have significant financial relationships with the authority.

Spending Patterns

Unlike some neighbouring councils, Rossendale shows a very flat spending pattern throughout the financial year. March spending — the final month before the year-end deadline — runs at just 1.1x the monthly average. This is a positive indicator: year-end spending spikes can suggest budget rush behaviour, where departments accelerate spending to avoid returning unspent funds.

The absence of a spike at Rossendale suggests either disciplined budget management or that the council's spending is largely committed through contracts and recurring payments rather than discretionary procurement.

Data Quality Assessment

Rossendale's published spending data scores well on several quality metrics:

  • Descriptions: 100% of transactions include payment descriptions — the best rate among the four East Lancashire councils
  • Departments: 100% of transactions are attributed to a council department
  • Micro-transactions: 30% of transactions are under £100, which is a high proportion but reflects the council's decision to publish below the £500 Transparency Code minimum
  • Transparency gap: 3,167 transactions (7.4%) have withheld supplier names — the most significant data quality concern

DOGE Analysis Findings

Automated analysis of Rossendale's spending data has identified several areas warranting further investigation:

  • £3.5 million in likely duplicate payments (1,948 high-confidence duplicate groups)
  • £132,100 in suspected split payments (transactions structured to fall below approval thresholds)
  • £8.1 million in round-number payments over £5,000 (may indicate estimates rather than invoiced amounts)
  • Benford's Law anomaly (statistical deviation in leading digit distribution, which can indicate data irregularities)
  • 22 suppliers shared with neighbouring councils, with some showing significant price gaps for similar services

Political Context

Rossendale Borough Council operates under Labour majority control, holding 19 of 30 seats (with 1 vacancy). The Conservative group forms the official opposition with 5 seats. As a Labour-controlled authority, spending decisions and budget priorities reflect the administration's political programme.

Methodology: All figures are derived from Rossendale Borough Council's published spending data for the period April 2021 to December 2025. The dataset comprises 42,536 transactions totalling approximately £64 million across 1,525 suppliers. DOGE analysis was performed using automated pattern detection for duplicates, split payments, round numbers, and Benford's Law compliance. Cross-council comparisons use equivalent published datasets from Burnley, Hyndburn, and Pendle.
